title: Do You Have A Job?
question_text:
A suburban high school wondered if their students had part-time jobs outside of school. The school counselor decided to survey the students at the high school and ask them if they had a part-time job and if they did, how many hours they worked. The data, broken down by class in school, is summarized below.
Which of the following is not supported by the graph?

choices.text: Freshman has the highest proportion of students with no job.

Sophomores work 5
to <10
hours more than any other group.
A majority of juniors and seniors have a part-time job.
Juniors have the second lowest proportion of students without a part-time job.

Seniors have the highest proportion of students who work 10+
hours.

solution:
Solution

Remember: the question asks us to find the choice that is not supported by the graph.

The information given in this problem is summarized in a segmented bar graph. The data on the graph represents two categorical variables. To compare the proportions for all four variables, we examine the stacked columns of the graph.

When looking at the
5
to
<
10
category, sophomores have an approximate proportion of
0.18
. But, looking at the senior column, they have an approximate proportion of
0.20
that work
5
to
<
10
hours. Therefore, the sophomores do not have the highest proportion who work
5
to
<
10
hours.

Choice 'B' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Freshman do have the highest proportion of students who do not have a part time job. This is true.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Since over
50
%
of all juniors and seniors work at least
1
hour, a majority of juniors and seniors do have a part-time job. This is true.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Only the seniors have a smaller proportion of students without a part-job, the juniors do have the second lowest proportion of students without a part-time job. This is true.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Looking at the
10
+
category, the seniors do have the highest proportion of all age groups with about
25
%
of students working
10
%
hours. This is true.
